div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Slightly warmer weather has prevailed since Saturday but on the whole it has been pleasant.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: THE AUSTRIAN TRAVEL INFORMATION BUREAU.

B6, PICCADILLY, LONDON, W. The most dellghtful and health-giving j resorts for Anglo-Bgyptian Officials are the I Alpine districts of Austria, which can be reached In a few hours from Trieste. Excellent Hotels (to suit every pocket) abound situated in high latitudes of great recuperative power specially recommended by doctors for those who have spent a con- siderable time in a hot climate. Various high Anglo-Egyptian Officials have already engaged villas, rooms at hotels, etc., for the ensuing vacation teason. Shootings and Fithlnga (at very low prices) can be arranged through the Bureau, also Castles and Villas can be let or sold. The full oat Information as to oost or tours, travelling and on every point will be sent by the Bureau on recipt of request

div.head: THE WAR
div.p: April 1.
Oyarna announces that natives report that the Russians who were at Hailung, 87 miles fo the south west ot Kirin, have retreated north- ward. The enemy is now concentrating at Kirin. (Reuter.)

div.head: PREPARING FOR SIEGE OF VLADIVOSTOK
div.p: St. Petersburg, April 1
Ten - trains are leaving Russia daily laden with commissariat and war material consigned to Vladivostok for the forthcoming siege.

div.head: A JEWISH DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: St. Petersburg, April 1.

The delay in the elaboration of the legislative scheme greatly disappoints the Russian re- formers. A number of arrests of revolutionary sus- ppots have been made here. It is reported that they include several “terrorist” leaders. (R.)
St. Petersburg, April 1.

Shadowing high officials here by three men disguised as sleigh drivers, led to the arrest of a band of 12 revolutionaries and the seizure of a regular bomb laboratory. Their papers show that they were acting under the direc- tion of a committee in Switzerland. (R.)
St. Petersburg, April 1. The Russian papers report that 70 Japanese prisoners have committed suicide in the govern- ment of Novgorod, but only one suicide is officially admitted.

div.head: OFFICIAL DENIALS PLENTIFUL.
div.p: Washington, April 1.
Mr Roosevelt’s mediation between Russia and Japau is authoritatively denied heie
London, April 2.
Official denials of “peace parleying” are plentiful, hut a firm conviction prevails on the Paris, and St. Petersburg bourses that peace is approaching.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: Perim, April 1.
Admiral Nibopatoff’s third Baltic squadron has passed this island making for Djibouti. ( Reuter.)

div.head: JAPANESE INTERNAL LOAN.
div.p: Ttycio, April 1;
The internal loan, mentioned on the 23rd Fehruary, has been covered five times. £70,000,000.of the subscriptions are above the issue price.

div.head: FIGHTING IN. ARABIA.
div.p: Jeddah, April 1.
A large Turkish force has arrived at Saana.
Lodz, April 1.
The commissioner of police here has been seriously wounded by a bomb in the street. The assailant was- cut down by a policeman and taken to the hospital.
Warsaw, April 2.
A demonstration was made by the Jews to- day in memory of their ancestors. The troops dispersed the crowd, killing four of them and wounding forty.

div.head: SPEECH BY M. DELCTASSU
div.p: M. Delcassd, speaking, in the Senate, said that France seeks to establish her interests in Morocco not on the basis of a disregard for the interests of others, but rather that her interests and those of the other Powers should he in harmony. The Mediterranean Powers have recognised that France, owing to her position in Algeria, must occupy a special position in Morocco. It might be legitimately hoped that France, without infringing any rights or interests, would succeed in- assuring her influence in the western Mediterranean.

div.head: FRANCE AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: Hodeidah, April 2.
Private advices say^that the Turkish troops before reaching Saana had a sharp fight. Details are lacking.
RAILWAY INTERNATIONALISATION OPPOSED.
Paris, April 1.

M. Delcassd, questioned in the Senate, stated that the Government was opposed to the internationalisation of the FrancorEthio- pian Railway. It will make Djibouti an open port should it think it proper, and will take every step to assure the independence of Ethiopia.
Paris, April 2.
M. Delcassd, speaking in the Senate, said that the Government did not favor the internationalisation of the Ethiopian railway, and would not make Djibouti a free port unless it thought fit

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Tourist Steamer.—The S.S. “Orient,” with a large Dumber of tourists on board, is due at Alexandria to morrow morning.

Land and General Trust, Ltd. — The shares of this company will be offered /or public subscription in the course of a few dlys. Fire at Dessouk.—The damage caused by the conflagration at Dessouk, which broke out last Tuesday night and destroyed sixty shops, is estimated tat about L E. 4,000.
POPULAR DEMONSTRATION.

Fayoum.—The High Municipal Commission is at the present time considering a scheme for lighting Medinet el-Fayoum by means of electricity by the help of waterfalls. Rome, April 2. The Duke jfnd. Duchess of Connaught are siting the city with Prince Gustavus Adolphus ' Sweden and Norway. They are being much ted. The Duke of Connaught and the King spected the barracks amidst an enthusiastic pular demonstration. (Reuter.)
Burglary.—A house in the Daher quarter of Cairo was broken into and robbed by burglars on Friday night. The ghaffirs did not detefct the robbery till the following morning. ZAMBESI BRIDGE COMPLETED.

Schweppes.—The directors recommend the full dividends on the Preference and Ordinary Shares and a dividend of 2 per cent, for 1904 on the Deferred Shares. For 1903 the Deferred received 3 per cent Capetown, April 1. . Bovine Typhus. — Twenty-four cases of ' The bridge over the Zambesi\at the Victoria bovine typhus were reported throughout Egypt Palls has been practically completed. last week. The total number of deaths recorded since the commencement

div.head: The Sucreries Company
div.p: the Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d’Egypte Company has appointed M. Henri Naus as technical director,and M. AttilioNinci as com mercial director of the company. The Plague.—During last week four cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt, three of which occurred at Tant el-Ghezireh, Toukh district, and one at Maghagha, Minieh pro- vince. One case is reported from Tonkh to-day.
FOOTBALL AT CRYSTAL PALACE.

Lots Tcrcs. — We are infom/ed by the Alexandria agency of the Credit Lyonnais that the winning number in Saturday's drawing of Turkish Railway Lottery bonds in Constanti- nople was 467,273, the possessor of whom is Nile Valley.—The London Stock Exchange Committee has appointed Wednesday, April 12, as a special settling d(iy for Nile Valley Block E. Limited—Further issue of 3,500 shares of £1 each fully paid, Nos. 26,501 to 30,000.

Suez Canal:—On the 29th and 30th March 23 vessels passed through the canal, the re- ceipts for the two days being frs. 638,323.36. Of the ships 16 were British, 1 Dutch, 3French, 2 German, 2 Turkish. The total receipts from the 1st of the month were frs. 10,267,017.36, A Soldier’s Exploit.—While the troopship "Soudan” was at Suez, recently, a man belonging to the Lancashire Regiment made a wager to swiiq from the ship to the shore. The water was infested with sharks, but the soldier reached land in safety.

div.head: Case of Arson
div.p: In consequence of an inquiry into the recent fire at Dessouk, two shopkeepers named Mahmoud Aly Moussa and Mahfouz Abd el Latif have been arrested- They will be brought before the Tantah Assize Court on a charge of setting their own build- ing on fire.

The “De Profundis” of Oscar Wilde has been issued in Methuen’s Colonial Library and can be obtained at Messrs. Diemer’s and Zacharia’s bookstalls in Cairo. The work is well got up and printed and is published at a very.moderate price. The criticisms on this little masterpiece, which have^ appeared in all the London papers, dispense us from giving any detailed notice of the work.

Ghezireii Palace Hotel.—The net profits on the Ghezireh Palace Hotel this season have been larger than during any previous season at this hotel. The number of visitors at the hotel is steadily increasing and it is becoming every year more fashionable. It was believed that this hotel was a “drag” on Shepheard’s, but this opinion is quite un- bounded, and the Ghezireh Palace is now one of the most profitable hotels in Egypt. H.M.S. “Heckla” (Capt. Edward F. B. Charlton), torpedo depOt and machinery ship for repairs, arrived at Port Said on Saturday and entered the Canal yesterday for China. The last time the “Heckla” went' through the Canal was in 1884 on the way to Suakin, in charge of Captain A. K. Wilson, who got his V. C. at El Teb. Admiral Sir Arthur K. Wilson is now in command of the Channel Fleet.

Trade oF Trieste. — The latest Diplomatic and Consular report issued by the Foreign Office shows that during 1904 there was again a general increase in the goods traffic of Trieste. During the yefir 9,983 vessels of 2,948,446 tons entered the port, which was 65 less than in 1903, but an increase in the tonnage. Of the imports of ooal into Trieste the British product hfcld the first place, as out of the total of 350,000 tons imported 290,000 were received from the United Kingdom.

Appointment for Anolo Eoyptlan. — Mr. Samuel Simpson, B. Sc., formerly senior lecturer in agriculture at the School of Agriculture^ Cairo, has been appointed agricultural expert to the British Central Afrioa Protectorate, and left-Cairo yesterday to take up his new duties. His work will be chiefly in connection with the extension of cotton cultivation there, but he will advise in all matters relating to agri- culture. He embarked on the Austrian Lloyd boat at Suez to-day, and has to report himself at Chinde before going up the Zambesi to Blantyre and Zomba.

div.head: England and .Islam.
div.p: A correspondent writes to the “Morning Post” in reference to the proposed mosque in London, suggesting that the King should be approached by the Pau-Islamic Society with the object of securing his patronage, and, that advantage having been gained, that the appeal for subscriptions should not be restricted to Mussulmans only, for although there is no doubt that the Mussul- man community will beable to bnildthe mosque unaided, it would give an opportunity to the Christian population of England to show proof that the age of prejudice and bigotry is past.

div.head: COMPANY PROMOTER CONVICTED.
div.p: A company promoter, of the name of Joseph Feldmann, was sentenced to. six months’ im- prisonment with hard labour on Saturday last by the Cairo Native Court of 1st Instance. He was charged with obtaining £400 from an American citizen, Mr. Rogow. Feldmann introduced Mr. Rogow to Mr. Hi Hadyn Bartlett, well-known in Egypt in con- nection with the abortive flotation of the Egyptian Cold Storage scheme. The latter had founded the Eagle Soap Company, which was to have had a capital of £40,000, divided into 40,000 shared- of £1 eaoh, of whioh 25,000 shares were to be allotted to the vendors in payment of the purchase price, and 5,000 for purposes of working capital. Mr. Bartlett was the solicitor to the company. Feldmann succeeded in getting £400 from Mr. Rogow for the purpose of obtaining a patent for soapmaking, and the. Court held that the money was obtained -by fraud. Feld- mann had been at one time a restaurateur on one of the boats plying on the Second Cataract reach.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest lit olaea and most oomfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Centra) position. Under English management

div.head: NOTES FROM KHARTOUM.
div.p: Bishop Morley arrived here on Friday, 24th inst., and aooeptod the hoepitality of Major fhipps, oommaudint, Khartoum distriot On Saturday afternoon!, Major Phipps, who is also the popular secretary to the Church Fund, had a congregational tea party at the “Grove” to meet the Bishop^which was largely attended. At the morning servioe on Sunday, the Bishop held a confirmation, three candidates being presented, and in. the evening his lordship preached the sermon. This morning (Tuesday), Bishop Morley laid the foundation stone of the new C.M.S. School for girls in Victoria avenue, being assisted by the Rev. Gwynne, bead ot the C.M.S. Mission here, and the Rev Paxton, British Chaplain at Khartoum. There Was a short servioe, with a good attendance. The Bishop returns North this atemoon. As regards the C.M.S. School, this is making distinot progress, and tha number of children is inoraasiag daily, being already over 100, mostly Egyptian and Sudanese. THE KHEDIVE. The Khedive returned to Abdeen Palace this morning and left the Palace to open the extraordinary meeting of the General Assembly of the Legislative Council. His Highness then returned to Abdeen, where he gave audienoe to Prince Aly Fadel, M. Raphael Suarts, the Judicial Adviser, who presented his report for the past year to his Highness, Sir R. Hanbury Brown, and Idris Bay Ragheb. The members of the General Assembly came to Abdeen and thanked the Khedive for open- ing the session of the Assembly. / i In the afternoon his Highness will givfe audience to Ghaai Mukhtar Pasha and Mr. Reboul. His Highness will inaugurate the exhibition of the Alexandria Horticultural Society at San Stefano at 4 p.m.

div.head: RAILWAYS ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: Mr. B. R. Marreilier has been appointed Inspector-General of Audits in. the Egyptian State Railways, and! leaves Alexandria to take up his new duties to-morrow. Mr. -Marrullier has gained a great knowledge of accounts in the offioes of Messrs. Carver Bros. & Co., Ltd., and is, in the opinion of those best capable of judging, well qualified for the very important work he will have to undertake. In lieu of entertaining his friends to a farewell sapper hi has made donations of £6 to the Alile Rudolph, and £5 to the Foundlings’ Home, Alexandria. Mr. Sbephaard has been transferred to the Aocounte Department of the Egyptian State Railways. Mr. F. V^oodley Page, who has been aoting as Militant to Mr. Suepheard for some years past, has been officially appointed to suooeed Mr.Sbepbeard m superintendent of stores. This is a well-deserved promotion, and has caused great satisfaction.

div.head: CAIRO’S WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes :—About two years ago, when Cairo, and especially the fashionable Ismailia quarter, was left for two or three days withou); water, the Water Com- pany gave the public the assurance that snob a calamity would never occur again, and in- formed them at the tame time that they were about to construct new filters high enough to force the water up to the Savoy Hotel.'tower, Since then things, instead of improving an everybody hoped, hate gone from bad to worse. In the IsAiailia quarter the water supply has got “smaller by degrees and beautifully lees,’’ until now the inhabitants of the third stories are literally without water from about 7 a.m. up to 4 or 5 p.m. If this is the case in winter what will it be in summer t The Water Com- pany speaks of good profits made in the past year ; one oannot be astonished at this good result Money is oollected for water which is .not supplied.

div.head: NOTES PROM SUEZ.
div.p: Sues, Sunday.

The Italian cruiser "Liguria,” commanded by H.R.H. the Duke of the Abrussi, entered the Canal at II o’clock this morning bound to Spezzia, after calling at Alexandria. The Italian Diplomatic^AgentatCairo, accom- panied by the Suez Vioe-Consul, Mr. Deperais, paid au official visit to the ship at 9 a.m. and the usual salute of seven guas was fired. The Italian gunboat “Galileo,” from Massowah, bound to Taranto, entered the Carnal this morning at 7 o’clock.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner “Seti” arrived at Malta yesterday morning homeward bound. The Messageries Maritimes S.S. “Salazie,” from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow. The Khedivial Mail S.S. “Ismailia” will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Pirseus, Smyrna, Mitylene and Constantinople.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: The council of Viotoria College has decided to purohase a large plot of land, about sixteen feddans in extent, at San Stefano, for a new site for the oollege. The present site has become insufficient for the growing needs of the oollege. The new ground is admirably situated at the Ramleh end of the Alexandria ttramways and on the main road from the city. We feel sure that any slight inconvenience whioh distance from the town might give rise to for day pupils will be more than balanced by the healthiness of the new position. We omitted to mention in our report of the athletio sports at Victoria College that the head-master and Miss Lias were “at home” to their many friends and'to the pupils’ parents on that afternoon.

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS.
div.p: The negotiations in regard to the constitu- tion of the Upper Egypt Hotels Company are oonclnded, and tire basis tin which the company is to be constituted is definitely settled. The negotiations for the acquisition of tire Savoy Hotel at Assouan have oome to an end, and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotels Company will remain- outside the group. The Upper Egypt Hotels Company, in addition to acquiring the Cataract and the Grand Hotels at Assouan, intend bnilding a magnificent hotel there. EGYPTIAN ESTATES. The following notioe in regard to the Egyptian Eitetes, Limited, appeared in the London newspapers of Saturday, the 25th ulto.— . , The first batch of letters of allotment and regret have been posted, but, owing to the large number of applications, it has been impossible to prepare cheques in return of moneys due on over-payments. We are informed that cheques will be posted not later than Monday next.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: La salle da Zinnia dtait exceptionnellement garnie hier soir pour entendre los Coquelin d»n» lee deux comddies do Molidro, "Lo Malade Imaginaire” et “Le Mddeoin malgrd Ini”. Dans la preraidre M. Jean Coquelin jouait le rfile d’Argan, le malade par auto-suggestion, qu’il a fort bien interprets. M. Coquelin Cadet a dtd un Diafoirus iddal de bdtise; Mme Bouchetal a dtd trds bien dana son r6le de servante aviade, Milo Maufroy dojeunefille spirituelle autant que bien nde, Mile Damaury de marAtre hypo- crite et intdressde.

Dans "le Mddeoin malgrd lui” M. Coquelin Cadet jouait le rdle do Sganarolle qu'iljntor- prdte k la Comddie Fran^aise. II n’est pas besoin de dire si l'interprdtation a dtd bonne; do .commencement k la fin l’hilaritd a dtd gdndrale. M. Jean Coquelin a dtd naif A souhait en bonhomme Lucas, Mme Bouchetal trds bien, comme dTiabitude, dans son rdle de Martine et Mile Damaury dans celui de Jacqueline. Co soir la Cie Coquelin Cadet fait ses adieux aveo "Cadet Roussel," oomddie en trois aote3 de J. Richepin.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: II y a eu co matin une grande animation snr les prinoipales valours, la Banque Nationals, 1'Agricole, la Delta Light et la Daira. Le chiffre d'affaires a dtd surtout dnorme en Agricole.

La Banque National© a ddbutd k 27 5/16, at- taint 3713/16 pour retomber encldtnre k 37 5/8. L’Agrioole a ddbutd k 13, attaint 13 13/16 -pour fiuir a 13 9/16. Li Delta Light a tbuchd le prix da 14 7/8 k un moment donnd, mais en cldtnre le cours a tldchi k 14 5/8. De 36 5/16 la Daira ahaussd jasqu’k 37, pour clOturer k 26 5/8.

Le Crddit Foncier a attaint 329 achetenrs. D’autres valeurs sont dgalement en hausse, mais plus Idgdre: Ainsi l'Oasis remonte k 1 3/16. los Estates k 13/8, la Salt & Soda k 41/3, l’Anglo-American Nile A 5 13/16 et la Ramleh Railway k 8 3/16. L’ensemble du marchd est excellent aveo trds bonne tendance.

Siege Social, 106 Rue Royals Bruxelles. Le Conseil d’Administration a l’honneur de porter k la connaissance do Messieurs les Ac- tionnairee que l’Assemblde Gdndrale Ordinaire aura lieu k Bruxelles le Merorodi 3 Mai 1905, A 3 heurea de l’aprds-midi,Rue du Marais.55.

ORDRE DU JOUR 1 °/ Rapports du Conseil d’Administration et du College des Commissaires sur lee exer- oioes 1903-1904.— 27 Approbation des Bilans et du Compte des ProfitsetPertes des exercicos 1903-1904.— 3°/ Nomination d’Administrateure et d’un

Commissaire au Cairo.— Pour Ctre admis k l’assemblde, Messieurs les Aotionnaires auront k bo con former k l’articlo 32 dee struts. Les actions doivent Ctre ddpo- sdes k Bruxelles, k la Banque BaLser & Co. En Egypte, dans l’un dee dtablissemente financiers oi-aprda nommds: Banque Impdriale Otto mane, Bank of Egypt, Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd., National Bank of Egypt, Crddit Lyonnais,Banque d’Athdnes et Cassa di Soonto e di Risparmio.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Assemblde Gdndrale annuelle de l'Alex- andria General Produce Association do 29 Mars 1905, a ddcidd d’apporter au Rdglement des oontrats de coton, los modifications sui- vantes: Page 18 — Remplacer l'aotuel art. 6, comme suit: Art 6 — La base des opdrations en Contrats est le "fully good fair brown". Les provenances de la Haute-Egypte et du Fayoum ne pourront Ctre livrdes qu’avec la diffdrence que le Comitd A- rduni au Comitd des Courtiers en Marohandises, fixera au cours des trois derniors jours, non-fdrids, de chaquo mois, pour le mois suivant En outre, pour avoir cette facultd, le vendeur devra fairo une bonification suppldmentaire fixe de P.T. 7 1/2 par Cantor do 100 Rotolis. Tout Contrat fait pour qualites autres que "fully good fair brown" est dgalement souinis au prdsentRCglement. Los affaires frauoo station sont aussi sou- misos au prdsent Rdglement Lo prix des Contrats est fixd par Cantor de 100 Rotolis poids net Page 19 — Remplacer los aOtuels art 7 et 7 Bis, comme suit: Art 7. — La bonification mutuelle est ap- pliqudo, sauf stipulations spdciales sur les Lettres Contrats, k tous les Contrats do "fully good fair brown" et de "fully good fair" Haute- Kgypto et Fayoum. La bonification mutuelle comprend un olas- sornont au-dessous et an classement au-dessus. Remplacer le second paragraphe de l’art 8, commo suit: Art 8.— Second paragraphe. Ils ont toutefois la faoultd de liner depuis "goodfair" jusqu'k "good’ moyennant bonifi- cation mutuelle (du vendeur k l’aohoteur ou vico-vorsa) des diffdrences do prix entre cos olassements et lej "fully good fair" fixdes pour le mois de'livraison par le Comitd A- rduni au Comitd des Courtiers en Marohandises. Page 28 — Remplaoer le premier paragraphe de Part 40, oomme suit -. Art 40.— Premier paragraphe. Le vendeur est tenu de remplaoer dans les 72 heures (les jours fdrida exolus) par une se- conds elder nitre liyraison de Coton reoevable, tout Coton rejetd par les experts, comme n’d- tant pas livrable.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration de la National Bank of Egypt a l’jionneur de porter k la con- naissauce des intdressds quo PAssemblde Gdnd rale Ordinaire des Aotionnaires rdnnie le Lnndi 20 Mars, 1905, an Sidge Social,' an Cairo, a fixd k 14 shelliDgs lo montant du dividende k payer par action pour Pqxeroioe olos le 81 Ddcembro 1904.— Ce dividende est payable centre remise du ooupon No. 5 k partir du 23 Mars 1905, an Silge Social de la Baoqne, au Caire, k sa Suo- oursale k Alexandrie, dans ses Agencesdos Provinoes et k son Agenoe de Londres 4 & 5, Jting William Street. 25628-8*-2

div.head: ALEXANDRIA BONED WAREHOUSE
div.p: The Coupon No. 6 is payable at the rate of £2.8.0 per share of £20, at tho offices of the Credit Lyonnais, from tho 3rd April 1905.

div.head: MESOPOTAMIA
div.p: BY SIR WILLIAM WILLCOCKS.

“And it • came, to pass as they journeyed East, that they found a plain in the land of Shinar; and they dwelt there.” This is the description of one of the earliest settlements hi Mesopotamia, the country irri- gated by the Euphrates and the Tigris, and constituting the true delta of the two rivers. If it were necessary we could go back to the garden of Eden of which the traditional site is occupied to-day by the palm groves of Guma, the point of junction of the Euphrates and the Tigris, and from where I have obtained a specimen of the soil and had it analysed. . No irrigation engineer who has travelled through the ^country can have tailed to have been struck by the great/difference between the delta of the Nile on the one hand and the joint delta of the Euphrates and thh Tigris on the other. The Nile is in Hood from August to October, the turbid flood waters can be retain--, ed on the land in the historical basins of Egypt, and discharged back into the falling river in November. This, permits of the winter cultivation of the rich fields of wheat, barley, beans, and clover. Such a system of irrigation is impossible in Mesopotamia. The. rivers are in flood in March, April and May, while the floods are followed by the burning and rainless months of June, July and August, in which irrigation must' be practised if any crop is to be brought to maturity. So that while Egypt was the home of basip irrigation for thousands of years, Mesopotamia was the home of perennial irrigation. This latter class of irrigation needs far ra'ore skill and knowledge of hydraulics than basiii irrigation, and consequently one is great'v struck by the remains of the ancient regulators arid irrigation works whose ruins are to be,met with in the Euphrates valley, while there are no remains of any such works in Egypt. ■The' basin system of irrigation introduced by the ancient Egyptians was entirely in keep- ing with the ancient structures of the type of the pyramids. It could defy time and even defy neglect. It was on this account that it survived every revolution and every trouble of many thousands of years ; while its rival, the perennial irrigation \of the Euphrates valley, • fell utterly into rain and decay. Of the Euphrates valley it was prophesied, as could never have been prophesied of ancient Egypt, “And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of ' the Chaldees’ excel- lency, shall not be dwelt in from generation to generation.” Perennial irrigation is no hardy plant like basin irrigation, it needs perpetual and constant attention ; it is typical of the structures of Our days, the dams and weirs on the Nile, which have accompanied the intro- duction of perennial irrigation in Egypt, and which need observation and attention to pre- serve' them iijrtact. Modern Egypt is not satis- fied with that basin irrigation which has come down from the'- remotest antiquity, but is conferring on the length and breadth of the Nile valley that perennial irrigation which the Euphrates valley enjoyed dor thousands ot years and which struck the imagination of every traveller who saw Babylonia in the days of her glory. ,v Armed with experience of perennial irriga- tion and sub-tfopicil agriculture, which lias been gained in Iudii\and Egypt through thirty years of uninterrupted work as an irrigator and agriculturist, I propose with • assurance the re introduction of perennia irrigation into the historical' regions which In around Babylon and Bagdad, Selucia and C.tesiphoii, arid Opis where lay the head works of the greatest irrigation canals of antiquity. The irrigation and high cultivation of ancient Babylonia Was a problem which was mastered in its entirety by the Chaldean sages of old, hydraulic engineers of no mean order ; the problem before us is no harder, and modern science is sufficiently in advance of ancient science, to justify the hope that the land will again become the garden of the East, and thai we shall again see “men’travelling to the East and finding a' resting place in the plains of Shinar.”

div.head: UNDER THE MOSQUITO NET
div.p: "As I lay thinking"

In the concluding portion of my remarks last week I spoke of the reasons that so many people urge for restricting the study and practise of occult gifts. Many good people who never think of denying their existence attri- bute them to Satanic agency, and warn their friends that it is all “the work of the devil.” Substitute “the spirit of evil” for “the devil” (I need hardly say that I have no belief in a personal-devil) and lam disposed to agree with much that is said as to the undesirability of increasing facilities for the practice of such gifts as clairvoyance, palmistry, hypnotism and the like. The knowledge of. the existence of such is one thing, the exercise of them i§ another, and it is not a -thing to be lightly attempted by tho°e who have only acquired a superficial acquaintance with the subject. In saying this I simply, give the result n many years! close" study of the matter from every point of view from which it can be regatded, and knowing full Well (as a correspon- dent reminded me in a letter to the editor the other day) that “a little knowledge is a dangerous thing,” I certainly recommend those who cannot give a lot of time and thought to investigation of snch matters, to leave them alone as much as possible, simply noting and thinking about such experiences out of the common as may fall to their lot. By no means should these be ignored, and the why and the wherefore should certainly be sought. And never should the existence of such forces as I have spoken of, and many others ori which I could dilate, be doubted. Some good people are giveu to assume that things that are narrated in the Bible belong to ages long past, and neVer occur now. And yet here in Egypt we see in the present day, at every turn we take, manners, customs, and scenes faithfully reproducing those described in the earlier books of the Bible, thousands of years old. And when we read of Saul seeking to learn from the clairvoyance of Samuel what had become of his father’s asses, what is there to distinguish the incident from the practice so common now-a-days of consulting a person gifted with “second- sight” (in like manner to Samuel) and obtaining information equally correct on matters of importance ? And why should the - modern magician be less able to call up the shades of the departed than the Witch of Endor ? Bring common sense to bear upon these questions and they will be found extremely difficult to answer. Long before I gave such things serious attention,' I read of a very gifted lady palmist in London, and as at the time I was in a state of great perplexity Idetermined to haveaconsulta- tion, which with some difficulty I obtained. My hand’showed that, at an age I was fast, approaching, a crisis in my life-would take place. In what way. this crisis would end was a question impossible to answer,, two entirely opposite solutions being shown in the “life line ” The palmist confessed herself unable to make any prediction on the point. In due time the crisis arrived, but it was surmounted, and*, the more favorable reading turned out to be the correct one, although I feel sure that the other was . expected when my hand was read. Why was this ? Simply, I think, because I exeroised my own free will, wd "the possession of this right rendered a precise forecast a matter of impossibility. Probabilities, yes 1 certainties, no 1. is the way I would sum up all attempts at prediction, marvellously correct as many turn out to be. A few years later I' again consulted a palmist. (I should say that on both occasions fees were absolutely refused). I was then told hat a certain event would happen in three years’ time, to be followed by results that were foreshadowed with equal precision.^The event predicted took place two years andteti months from the date of .the interview, and the results followed in due course. But I firmly believe that in this matter also I could have exerted my will in an opposite direction, and that only a probable event was indicated after all. The possession of free will by man may be a moot point; the facts I have stated are part of my own experience, and prove to me .conclusively the possession of powers by some that are far removed from charlatanry. And the fact that these powers are frequently put to wrong purposes and assumed by im- posters cannot blind the thinking mind to the fact of their existence. Now to Carry my argument a step further. Is it to be assunied that these gifts belong to the material body only and eease at the termination of physical life 1 Few would an swer in the affirmative. Then if they pereis- after the demise, of the mortal body what is to hinder their beiDg exercised from the unseen, and the phenomena, of spiritualism be he result ? And exercised they are, too, and with the increased power that freedom from the limitations imposed by the earth life involves. But may not earth life itself be divided . pto two portions, one of. which is lived in- the physical body and the second after the .irave has closed over the mortal remains? I am led to ask the question not from any wish to broach a new theory evolved in my own mind from- an attempt to reason the matter out, and devise a way out of some of the many difficulties that con- tinually force themselves upon my mind, but from practical experience, gained at what I know to have been considerable risk to myself, but through which I have come scatheless, and with a wealth of knowledge that I could not otherwise have possessed. Some day I may perhaps publish these ex- periences, at present I will content myself with stating the conclusions to which they have led me, and if I have whetted my readers’ appetite for more, I will return to the subject anon. The necessity tor com- pressing what I haye to say into a limited space must be my apology .'for brevity. These conclusions may best be stated by a, series of short propositions, some of them old as the hills and widely accepted, others of such a character that until they are w$ll thought over they look like the wanderings of a morbid and diseased fancy, which I am free to admit is the guise in which they would have present- ed themselves to me a few years back. They are however the outcome of long, serious, and prayerful study, as well as of much experience and observation of the various phases of human life, coupled with earnest effort never relaxed to arrive at truth. Leaving entirely out of consideration any question concerning what we are pleased to term the lower world, and starting with man at his present stage of evolution I would say in the first place,—That the conditions of this life are such that while if mankind were in a perfect state of development the earth life would be amply sufficient for its purpose to. be fully achieved by alL As life is now lived this is impossible.—That myriads pass into the unseen without ever having had a chance of learning its lessons and gaining its experience. Ergo,—That the spark of Divine life we all possess has had no chance of development in these cases—young children, for instance, and these whose earthly career is out short in an- untimely manner. That at what we term “death” a condition of life commences which is practically a conti- nuation of earth life, and in which opportuni- ties are afforded for the completion of the stage that should have been reached on the earth, but which from various causes became impos- sible there.

That from this stage many who have pre- pared themselves in earth life for translation to higher spheres, quickly pass, while others, equally advanced in mauy respects, are held back by their inability to sever the ties of human affection and other earthly attractions; and are consequently unable td progress so quickly; these latter being the higher entities which communicate throngh mediums. That all, from the very lowest and most degraded and ignorant of God’s ohildren remain in this stage until they have found salvation, have received the new birth and conquered the old lusts of the flesh. And finally and most important of all,—That we on earth can largely contribute to the advancement of these darkened - men and women by giving them our sympathies and prayers.

A long course of stances held with this sole object in view has convinced me of the practicability of this,—as well as the advisa- bility of abstaining from entering upon such work without special qualifications and train- ing.

But prayers for the departed) are daily becoming more and more common, and would be even more general if the good they do could only be more fully recognised. It is in this direction that mankind generally can do immeasurable good to help those , who have gone on before, to the progression awaiting' all sooner or later.

Rapid as is this survey of an interesting— nay engrossing— subjeot that I could enlarge upon with the enthusiasm of one who thinks he has made a great discovery, I have left much unsaid that ought to be Btated to make my position perfectly\slear, and have left mysell little room to deal with a matter that appears to me to be urgent and on .which I should like to say a few words at once.

I allude to the disclosures of the Cor- respondent of the “Gazette” at Assiout which appeared on Friday under the heading “Crime at Assiout.” Anything more disgraceful than these disclosures I can hardly imagine, nor caflf I believe that any one department of the internal affairs of the country wants a greater overhauling than the administration of justice in the rural districts.

That is of course presuming that the allega- tions are true. But perhaps a very exceptional .tate of affaire prevails at Assiout, and in that ase snch a state of things can be quiokly put an end to, in all probability.

I think he might have taken his beating with a better grace than to acouse me of want of politeness. A person who labels a scholarly work as “A Queer Grammar” without just cause, should be the last to raise the plea of politeness. In my letter, I was not exchanging courtesies with hith, but dealing justice. The matter is not a personal, but a public one. I am not surprised to hear that the reviewer is not foreign to the Arabic tongue,” as the English of his letter shows only too clearly that he is loreign to England and is probably better acquainted with bad Arabio than with good English.

In thd circumstances, I am sorry if I have used any expression that may have wounded his feelings, and the best compliment I' ««.n pay to him is that the English of his original article was so passable that I was deceived into thinking it was written by an English- man ; and 1 naturally resented the idea of. a countryman of my own commiting what 1 thought to be an injustice.

Now knowing the truth —as disclosed by the English of his letter — I can only humbly apologise tor quite unintentionally trouncing the wrong man ; but, at the same time, I must remind him, that there is a great difference between knowing his native tongue (Alex andrian or Syrian Arabic, I presume) an-.’ knowing the polite and cultured version of toe same tongue.— Yours, Grammar i vn.

P.S.—I must thank “Abu Shad-iof' (whose letter I have just seen) for his moral support, and congratulate him on the humour of his profound researches in the Khedivial Library on Bacon’s "Antony and C eopatra,” and the “congested” grammar of John Selden of 200 years ago. But when he pours the cold water of his shadoof on all grammars as a class, and suggests that they should all be sunk in the Assouan dam,—I humbly suggest that his plan is not drastic enough. While we have languages, we must have grammars ; and if the latter are a criminal offence, why then should we not end the Babel which causes them, and sink all languages ( except English ) in the Mediterranean 1 It would be interesting to hear native opinion upon this point.—G. Cairo, March 31, 1905.

div.head: Dr. Le Clerc's Pills for the Liver Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, Alexandria.
Allen, Alderson Co. Limited.
